visuals.title: ParticleArabText
visuals.description:
Based on https://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/377231.

I was mesmerised by the above sketch, so I decided to experiment with the idea (particle arrival using pixels from an image).

TIP: While experimenting with the idea of the above sketch, I discovered something valuable that could be useful to anyone using the Processing IDE (this does NOT apply to p5 or Processing.js): calling rect(x, y, 1, 1) with no stroke is dramatically faster than ellipse(x, y, 1, 1) and point(x, y). You can test this yourself by pasting this code into the Processing IDE: http://pastebin.com/LU8yXgmD

visuals.title: Amiga-Style Twister (Texture Mapped)
visuals.description:
A little math demo here. I have attempted to recreate the classic Twister demoscene effect, commonly implemented on Amiga systems throughout the 80s-90s. 

It's not as efficient as it could be (no sine tables, no efficient colour lookup), but it's pretty faithful.

I wrote a blog post with a little more info on how this demo works:
http://ddoodm.com/wordpress/?p=104

Enjoy! :)

visuals.title: Amiga-Style Twister (Texture Mapped)
visuals.description:
A little math demo here. I have attempted to recreate the classic Twister demoscene effect, commonly implemented on Amiga systems throughout the 80s-90s. 

It's not as efficient as it could be (no sine tables, no efficient colour lookup), but it's pretty faithful.

I wrote a blog post with a little more info on how this demo works:
http://ddoodm.com/wordpress/?p=104

Enjoy! :)

visuals.title: Fluid Simulation + Momentum Transfer + Electrostatic Force
visuals.description:
Mouse-interactive fluid simulation with particles.
The fluid simulation is solved on a 16x16 cell grid.
Using Verlet integration for the particle update.
Every particle has an electric charge and two of them have a static value. When any two  particles collide, they equally share it. The border is the electric ground. There's a nonlinear friction and on every collision there's a tiny amount of 1% energy lost, so its passive state approaches a global lower limit energy.
So far, the binding of the forces is one-way only and the particle motion doesn't add to the fluid simulation.
Have fun!

visuals.title: Poincare Hyperbolic Disk Tiling
visuals.description: This sketch illustrates an algorithm for drawing checkered patterns on the the Poincare disk. The Poincare disk is a model of hyperbolic geometry. The pattern is defined by reflections in the circles shown. For each point we check weather it is inside any of the circles. If not, it must be in that triangular space in the middle,  the only bit thats not inside any of the circles. So we draw that pixel white. Otherwise we repeatedly “reflect” the point until it finds its way to the middle triangle. We then colour it depending on weather it took an even or odd number of reflections.
visuals.instructions: Click on any point to see its orbit to the centre under multiple reflections.

visuals.title: Noise flow field painter
visuals.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:

visuals.title: Poincare Hyperbolic Disk Tiling
visuals.description: This sketch illustrates an algorithm for drawing checkered patterns on the the Poincare disk. The Poincare disk is a model of hyperbolic geometry. The pattern is defined by reflections in the circles shown. For each point we check weather it is inside any of the circles. If not, it must be in that triangular space in the middle,  the only bit thats not inside any of the circles. So we draw that pixel white. Otherwise we repeatedly “reflect” the point until it finds its way to the middle triangle. We then colour it depending on weather it took an even or odd number of reflections.
visuals.instructions: Click on any point to see its orbit to the centre under multiple reflections.

controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

visuals.title: Maze Generator: Randomized Kruskal's Algorithm
visuals.description:
Another maze generation program. This is one is a lot less fun than the last one but the code is a lot tidier and there is now a working solver. 

For more resources on Kruskal's algorithm, see:
* http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2011/1/3/maze-generation-kruskal-s-algorithm
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maze_generation_algorithm#Randomized_Kruskal's_algorithm
Basically, it puts the cells into sets, which are all merged (by removing a wall between them) until all the cells are connected. The colors you see are the sets.

Kruskal's algorithm generates perfect mazes with a uniform spanning tree.
visuals.instructions: Use the controls on the right. See description for more info.

visuals.title: expressivedance001
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Truchet explorer
visuals.description:
I've been playing a lot with Sebastien Truchet classic tilings lately. This sketch is intended to show its beauty and to share a simple codification of the patterns. 
There are 96 different combinations (classic Truchet tiles as appeared in 'Description des métiers', 1705).

· 'a' and 'd' keys: change the current tile
· 'w' and 'x' keys: change the zoom level.
Check browser title for tile reference and position in the set.

visuals.title: Console
visuals.description: Ever wanted to quickly check how some code works, not just in Javascript, not just in P5, but in OpenProcessing specifically? Type expressions into the console to see the output immediately. No need for "print" or "console.log" (execpt for loops). Look at the README for more details.
visuals.instructions: Type expressions, define functions, explore! The canvas for graphical functions like "ellipse()" is 200x200!

visuals.title: Tiling
visuals.description:
Left click to increase the number of tiles, right click to reduce. Space bar to save the picture. Number keys (1,2,3,4,5,6) to perform the following rules (at the limited resolution of 800x800, get code and modify to get higher res).
Rule 1: Randomized selection of the two tiles.
Rule 2: If the position of the tile is (x,y), then is x+y even or odd?
Rule 3: Is x*y even or odd?
Rule 4: Is sin(x+y)>0?
Rule 5: Is x>y?
Rule 6: Is x^y even or odd?

visuals.title: text011
visuals.description:
Digital Signature created by the transformation path of two randomly generated beziere curves. The text you see at the bottom of the sketch is the seed value for the random generator. Change the seed and see what happens.

Controls:
- TYPE SOMETHING = create seed
- MOUSECLICK = create random seed and generate signature
- BACKSPACE/DEL = delete last letter
- RETURN/ENTER/CTRL = confirm your seed and generate signature
- ALT = save image

visuals.title: Catch That Arial
visuals.description:
Arial and Helvetica are two typefaces that you cannot escape from in this modern life. If you pay (maybe just a little bit) attention to fonts, I guess this has occurs to you: Is that text in Arial or Helvetica? 

Read the stories between these two typefaces here: 

Indeed, they are very similar but still there are some clues to find. Click ↓and try to catch the Arial among the Helvetica-s!

visuals.title: Particle Text
visuals.description:
Based on https://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/377231.

I was mesmerised by the above sketch, so I decided to experiment with the idea (particle arrival using pixels from an image).

TIP: While experimenting with the idea of the above sketch, I discovered something valuable that could be useful to anyone using the Processing IDE (this does NOT apply to p5 or Processing.js): calling rect(x, y, 1, 1) with no stroke is dramatically faster than ellipse(x, y, 1, 1) and point(x, y). You can test this yourself by pasting this code into the Processing IDE: http://pastebin.com/LU8yXgmD
visuals.instructions: Click to reset the effect with particles starting at the mouse's position

visuals.title: Circular Network 2
visuals.description:
The program reads in .txt files and sorts nodes according to their sizes. The largest node is at 12'o clock position and the sizes decrease clockwise.

Color can represent another dimension of information, right now they represent the same information as size does. 

Red nodes always have their names displayed and other nodes display their names if you place your mouse over them.

You can adjust the THRESHOLD variable to display more edges. Most of the edges are 100% transparent now.

Thanks and enjoy! I will add some comments to my codes when I have time.

visuals.title: typehover poetry文字波动画
visuals.description: The FitnessGram Pacer Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The 20 meter pacer test will begin in 30 seconds. Line up at the start. The running speed starts slowly but gets faster each minute after you hear this signal bodeboop. A sing lap should be completed every time you hear this sound. ding Remember to run in a straight line and run as long as possible. The second time you fail to complete a lap before the sound, your test is over. The test will begin on the word start. On your mark. Get ready!… Start.

Another recode of something I've found. This time it's an isometric hand drawing which is quite popular at tumblr (http://alexjosephdiamond.tumblr.com/post/35885404062).  Noise is used for the displacement and a variation of my Image Triangulator (http://openprocessing.org/sketch/115409) sets the surface.

Controls:
PeasyCam
Space == new
0-9 == change resolutions
d == change display mode
r == base drawing on/off
t == origins drawing on/off
u == triangles drawing on/off

visuals.title: Image based triangulation
visuals.description:
Drawing machine based on http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/81905

Uses Lee Byron's Mesh Library:
http://www.leebyron.com/else/mesh/

Little bit slow because the triangulation has to be calculated every frame.

Controls:
Left mouse button = restart
Right mouse button = restart /w full resolution
1 / 2 / 3 = choose image
M = change movement mode
B = transparent background on / off
I = show / hide current input image
R = random image on / off

(Work in progress) Video:
https://vimeo.com/54590461

visuals.title: Image based targeting
visuals.description:
Parent sketch which turned into "Image based aggregation" (http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/80169). They both share the algorithm for the arrangement of the particles.

Controls:
P == Pause on / off
M == change movement mode
N == transparent background on / off
I == show / hide image input
R == random image on / off

Photos are taken by me.

visuals.title: Particle Text
visuals.description:
Based on https://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/377231.

I was mesmerised by the above sketch, so I decided to experiment with the idea (particle arrival using pixels from an image).

TIP: While experimenting with the idea of the above sketch, I discovered something valuable that could be useful to anyone using the Processing IDE (this does NOT apply to p5 or Processing.js): calling rect(x, y, 1, 1) with no stroke is dramatically faster than ellipse(x, y, 1, 1) and point(x, y). You can test this yourself by pasting this code into the Processing IDE: http://pastebin.com/LU8yXgmD
visuals.instructions: Click to reset the effect with particles starting at the mouse's position

visuals.description:
left click — remove/add background;
right click — add/remove pin;
click center — add/remove 

in processing it looks better

 The kanizsa illusion, named after the psychologist Gaetano Kanizsa, 
 shows how our brain can create the illusion that an object exists 
 when sections of a shape is removed.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ODdj9fhCMI

 #510 Mad tiler 
 http://geometrydaily.tumblr.com/post/58788031158/510-mad-tiler

leftClick  - rotate individual tiles.

keys:

  column is vertical, another /|\|/|

 6 - random diagonal tiles (no vertical);
 7 - square;
 8 - normal
